newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Hoarding lifts Swedish Match's July sales.
newsitem.headline: Hoarding lifts Swedish Match's July sales.

text.p: Swedish tobacco company Swedish Match said on Thursday that hoarding ahead of an August 1 tax hike on tobacco in Sweden boosted its domestic cigarette sales by 50-60 percent in July.
"We estimate hoarding lifted sales by 50-60 percent compared to a normal July month when we sell between 650 and 700 million cigarettes," Swedish Match spokesman Bo Aulin said.
The effects of hoarding was just as large for pipe tobacco and rolling tobacco, maybe even greater, Aulin told Reuters.
Hoarding affected sales of moist tobacco less, by 15-20 percent, partly because it is perishable and therefore hard to store, he said.

When Swedish tobacco tax rises on August 1 Swedish Match will raise cigarette prices by an additional 11 percent to 5.28 crowns a packet, lifting the price of a packet of Blend brand by a total of 22 percent to 44.50 crowns in the store.
Aulin expects the rise to decrease sales volumes by 10-15 percent.
"We are counting on a price flexibility on cigarettes of 0.6 percent which with a price hike of more than 20 percent would give a fall in sales volumes by 10-15 percent," Aulin said.

Swedish Match has also raised cigarette prices as the stronger dollar makes raw materials more expensive. The company hopes that it will be able to compensate for the expected tax-related fall in sales.

"The price hike is probably not enough to compensate for the fall (in sales) but hopefully there is a transfer to other products, mainly snuff and rolling tobacco, so we hope to keep or maybe even strengthen profitability," Aulin said.
